quote: We've taken action. The raid on the Solarium...
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It'll be forgotten by tomorrow.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Enter.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Mister Worf?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You want to make people leave Risa? I think I know a way.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I have to admit, I probably would've reacted the same way Worf did. I know Arandis was Curzon's lover, not yours, but if I'd walked in and seen the two of you together... trying to figure you out at any given moment isn't exactly easy.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I like that about her.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: So do I. It's why I chased after her for so long.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Would you please stop talking about me like I'm not here.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: But it's also why I stopped chasing her. You're too much work.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Worf is the one who's too much work.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: What you need is a Ferengi.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Maybe. But what I want is Worf.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Why?
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Because he has the courage of a berserker cat and the heart of a poet.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: And the brain of a pigheaded idiot.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Sometimes.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Any luck?
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I'm afraid not. None of the staff has seen him. But I'm sure he'll turn up.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Well, no sense waiting around here for him. I say we all take some floaters up into the hills and go skinny dipping in the hot springs.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I never thought I'd say this... but I'm with Quark.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: What was that?
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Great. Just what we needed.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I thought it wasn't supposed to rain in this part of Risa.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It's not. Something must've gone wrong with the weather grid.
scene: 53   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Could I please have your attention. Obviously the weather grid is experiencing some kind of malfunction. But I'm sure we'll be able to repair it soon.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: No you won't.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You're responsible for this?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I authorized it. But it wasn't my idea.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It was mine.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You're not serious.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: He's serious. What did you do, Worf? Build an uplink so you could take control of the weather grid?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: The grid has been deactivated. It'll take three or four days to restore the system to normal operation. During that time, the inhabitants of Risa and their guests will experience the planet's natural weather cycle.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: And for most of Risa, that means rain. And plenty of it.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: But why are you doing this?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Because Risa is an illusion created by weather control systems, industrial replicators, and seismic regulators.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: And if the Federation is going to survive, we're going to have to stop wasting our time with toys and get back to the essentials.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I'm beginning to think there's no hope for that man. or for you either, Mister Worf.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Commander, with all due respect... have you lost you mind?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I think you'll find me quite rational.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: As rational as Klingons get, anyway.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Worf, this is wrong.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I disagree. If Federation citizens cannot handle a little bad weather, how will they handle a Dominion invasion?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I've seen drier days on Ferenginar. And we have a hundred and seventy-eight different words for rain. Right now it's "glebbening" out there. And that's bad.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: If you're so unhappy, take your horga'hn and find some company.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Have you taken a good look at the Risians lately? They're even more depressed than the guests.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I'm trying to organize a game of hoverball. Would either of you like to join us?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: In the rain?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: No, on one of the indoor courts.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Indoor hoverball. That's just wrong.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I'll play.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Good, that makes one.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Having trouble keeping the guests happy?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I've never heard so much complaining in my life.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: No one came here to sit around in the rain.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It's not just the weather. People are starting to complain about everything. Their rooms, the entertainment, the food.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: What's wrong with the food?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Nothing, as far as I can tell. But the guests are starting to say it doesn't taste right.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It's the humidity. It dampens the food, makes everything mushy. Trust me. There's no word for "crisp" on Ferenginar.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Maybe Mister Fullerton is right. Maybe we have forgotten how to deal with adversity.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: According to our figures, the guest population has declined thirty percent in the last three days.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: And you can be sure the guests who've stayed are taking what you have to say seriously.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It's a start.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: One that you can build on. Good luck.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You're leaving?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I've had my fill of Risa.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Mister Worf, you've been an inspiration to us all.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You still have the uplink to the weather control grid?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Right here.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: By tomorrow, the weather grid will be restored to normal and no one here will remember this ever happened. But I intend to send a message they won't forget.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Their response only proves my point.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I see. You ruined the vacations of a few hundred thousand people to bolster the moral fiber of the Federation.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I don't expect you to understand.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I understand. Even better than you do. What you did had nothing to do with Risa, or the Essentialists, or the Federation. It was about you and me.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You give yourself far too much credit.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Do I? You think I'm irresponsible, frivolous. That I care more about pleasure than I do about commitment.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: (cutting to the heart of the matter) What do you think is going on between Arandis and me?
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You know what I think.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: That's right I do. And you know what? You're wrong. Did it occur to you to ask me about it? Or even trust, just a little?
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: A Klingon woman would never even give me grounds for suspicion.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: How would you know? Curzon spent more time around Klingons than you ever did.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You may have lived among my people, but you are not a Klingon. I am.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Maybe so. But you're not like any other Klingon I've ever met.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: What happened to you, Worf? You're a paragon of Klingon honor and discipline, but when it comes to the Klingon passion for life, the exuberance, the enjoyment of the moment, you're constantly holding yourself back. Why?
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: That's not the issue here.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I think it is.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I do not wish to lose you, Jadzia.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Then talk to me. Please.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You know that from the age of seven I was raised by humans on the farmworld of Gault?
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It was a sparsely populated world of not more than twenty thousand inhabitants. It often seemed as if everyone knew everyone else. But one thing was for certain... everyone knew me. I was the Klingon child. The "uncontrollable" one. I was the biggest, strongest, most fearless child on the entire planet. I fought hard, I played hard, I did as I pleased.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: What changed?
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: When I was thirteen, I was captain of my school soccer team. We made it to the championships, and I was determined to win. Near the end of the second half, with the score tied, my team got a corner kick. The ball sailed up high. Both I and one of my opponents, a human boy named Mikel, leaped up to head the ball. He had position, but I was determined to score. I remember laughing with excitement as I threw myself at him.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Go on.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: The next thing I knew, the ball was sailing into their goal. I roared in triumph and turned to Mikel, to gloat, only to find him lying on the grass bleeding. Our heads had collided when we went up for the ball. I didn't even feel the impact, but I'd broken his neck. He died the next day.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It was an accident.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Which only makes it worse. Compared to Klingons, humans are fragile creatures. I realized at that moment that to live among them I would have to practice... restraint.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: That must've been difficult for you.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: At first. But in time, it became part of who I was, who I am.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: And you're still afraid that if you lose control...
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Someone I care about might get hurt.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: That explains a lot. But you have to realize, there're some things in life you just can't control. And one of them is me. But what you can do is trust me. I care about you Worf. And I would never do anything to hurt you.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Nor would I do anything to hurt you.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Who knows, I might have more self- control than you give me credit for.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: That felt like an earthquake.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: so did that.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: The Essentialists.
scene: 61   INT. DAX AND WORF'S GUEST CHAMBER - DAY
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You should see them all run. I think they've finally realized that the party's over.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Increase the feedback in the tectonic stress regulators.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: If I do, there won't be a building left standing in this part of Risa.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: It might be a good idea to head for the spaceport. Or at least get out of this room.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Very well. I think we're done here.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: The uplink. Give it to me.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Mister Worf, I suggest you all get off this planet as soon as possible. I have no wish to see you or your friends harmed.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Give us the uplink or the only person who'll be "harmed" is you.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I thought you were one of us.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Perhaps I was... for a time. But I believe the Federation will survive the Dominion, the Borg... and even people like you.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: If you walk out of here now, you'll be turning your back on the Federation. Don't you see, overindulgence, lack of self-control, they'll destroy everything we hold dear. And you'll be responsible.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You say we have to return to traditional Federation values? I agree. But one of those values is trust. It is "Essential," we remember that.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Don't you walk away from me.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I'll do as I please. I'm on vacation.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Figures. The weather improves the day we leave.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I can't wait to get home. (to Arandis, apologetically) Not that I didn't enjoy myself.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I'd better go find Doctor Bashir. He brought a horga'hn down to breakfast and that's the last I saw of him.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I hope the two of you will visit Risa again.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I did not think I'd be welcome.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: You still have a lot to learn about my people.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I never got a chance to say good-bye to Curzon Dax.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: And you're not saying good-bye to me either. I'll be back.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Risa will be waiting.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: So what do we do now?
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Now... We watch the sun set.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I have a better idea. Let's go for a swim.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I don't have a bathing suit.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: I won't tell if you won't.
episode: Let He Who Is Without Sin ...

quote: Release docking clamps.
Clamps released.
Shields up. Power to phasers and quantum torpedoes.
Weapons ready.
Bring us around.
Dukat's bird of prey is in position.
Maintain communications blackout. Nobody fires until we have orders from Captain Sisko.
There sure are a lot of them.
That'll just make it harder for us to miss.
They still aren't responding to our hails.
I think they're trying to intimidate us.
I don't believe it. The Dominion ships are turning away from the station. They're laying in a new course. SISKO Heading?
Heading?
Straight for Cardassia.
Dukat's ship is breaking formation. He's going after the Dominion fleet.
Open a channel.
Dukat, stop trying to be a hero. Get back to the station.
Your concern is touching, major. But I think you misunderstand me. I'm not attacking the Dominion fleet... I'm joining it.
What are you talking about?
I'm afraid I have a confession to make.
For the past few months, I've been conducting secret negotiations between the Dominion and Cardassia. And as of last week, Cardassia has agreed to become part of the Dominion.
You can't be serious.
Good-bye, Major. You and I on the same side. It never seemed quite right, did it?
Lock phasers. open fire.
Too late. He's gone.
All clear.
The transmitter Tain used to contact the station. Where is it?
You have to crawl through the hole and kind of slide up into the wall.
It took him over a year to modify the old life-support system into a transmitter.
How did he operate it?
He wired the message and transmission coordinates directly into the system circuitry. That way all he had to do was connect the transmitter to the power grid and let it run.
Could the coordinates and message be changed?
You're planning to contact the runabout.
We could activate the transporters, beam ourselves onto the ship...
And run like hell.
Re-encoding the transmitter won't be easy. We'll have to reconfigure the array, one circuit at a time.
Can you do it?
Me?
I'm no engineer and neither is Mister Worf. But you, my dear Garak, are a man of many hidden talents.
If you can't do it, no one can.
It's nice to feel needed.
All prisoners assemble immediately.
I repeat. All prisoners assemble immediately.
Who's that?
Deyos. The Vorta who runs the camp.
No talking.
Touchy, aren't they?
All Cardassian prisoners, step forward.
I am pleased to announce that the hostilities between our peoples have ended.
As of today, Cardassia has joined the Dominion. Therefore, you are all being sent home. Congratulations on your new status as Dominion citizens.
Not you, Mister Garak.
Excuse me?
You're staying.
Perhaps there's been some sort of misunderstanding. The last time I checked, I was a Cardassian.
But not a very popular one, I'm afraid. At least not with the head of the new Cardassian government.
And who would that be?
Gul Dukat.

You might ask... should we fear joining the Dominion? And I answer you... Not in the least. We should embrace the opportunity. The Dominion recognizes us for what we are... the true leaders of the Alpha Quadrant.
And now that we are joined together, equal partners in all endeavors, the only people with anything to fear... will be our enemies.

My oldest son's birthday is in five days. To him and to Cardassians everywhere, I make the following pledge. By the time his birthday dawns, there will not be a single Klingon alive in Cardassian territory... or a single Maquis colony left inside our borders.
(continues, on the monitor) Cardassia will be made whole. All that we have lost will be ours again. And anyone who stands in our way will be destroyed.
This I vow with my life's blood. For my son... for all our sons...
Somebody tell me this is a bad dream.
It's no dream.
Well, I've got a vow to make too. The next time I see Dukat... I'm going to kill him.
Right now we have more immediate concerns. Such as who sabotaged our graviton emitters.

I don't know who it was, but they did a pretty thorough job. The emitters had the exact opposite effect from what we'd intended. They were supposed to collapse the wormhole's spatial matrix and close it forever. But instead they made the matrix even more stable. Not even trilithium explosives would destroy it now.
So the Dominion can send reinforcements through the wormhole whenever they want.
Looks like it's time for another round of blood screenings. Obviously we have a changeling infiltrator on the station.
What makes you think it's a changeling?
That's who I'd send.
I think Julian's right. Odo tells me that one of the Bajoran maintenance engineers has been missing ever since the Dominion fleet arrived in the Alpha Quadrant.
If that was our changeling, he's either gone... or assumed a new identity.
We can't afford to take chances. I want blood screenings and phaser sweeps. If he's out there, we've got to find him.
How long has he been in there?
Close to an hour.
Garak? How's it coming?
I only wish I were still in the Obsidian Order. This would make a wonderful interrogation chamber.
Tight quarters, no air, bad lighting, random electric shocks. It's perfect.
I'm glad you're enjoying yourself.
If you'd like, I'd happily trade places with you.
I suppose you could give me a crash course in Cardassian field engineering. I'd probably be ready to take over from you in... five or six weeks.
Quiet.
It's time.
I'm ready.
I've been looking forward to this.
So have I.
Give me a hand.
Hold on, Garak.
Wait.
Just a little while longer.
I thought I would be fighting Ikat'ika.
I wouldn't be so eager if I were you. This is his handiwork.
He has much to answer for.
His time will come. (getting back to the matter at hand) Now remember, every time you hit the ground, you must touch one of those posts or forfeit the match.
Today we train against a worthy adversary. Observe. Analyze. Remember. Soon, we will face his people in combat. The lessons you learn here will ensure victory. Victory is life.
Victory is life.
Begin.
Come on.
Clear.
That... was thoroughly unpleasant.
I'm fine. It's just... hotter in there than I thought. I got a little lightheaded. Give me a minute and I'll go back in.
You need more than a minute. Your pulse is racing. And I don't even want to think about your blood pressure. Maybe you should wait until tomorrow.
Do you want to get off this hellhole or not?
You know I do.
Then let me get back to work.
Rest for five minutes. And from here on in you take a fifteen minute break every hour. Doctor's orders.
Was that the best you have to offer?
He was our youngest and least experienced. I promise, your next opponent will provide more of a challenge.
The view's even better from Upper Pylon Two.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: I keep hoping the wormhole will open. That Garak's runabout will come through and everything will be all right again.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: Maybe it will.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: My father says Garak's dead.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: Right now I wouldn't believe your father if he said rain was wet.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: I used to think my father was a hero. That even when he did something bad, he had a good reason.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: Everyone has their reasons. That's what's so frightening. People can find a way to justify any action, no matter how evil.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: You think my father is evil?
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: I think you can't judge people by what they think or say... only by what they do.
scene: 53   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: We're being hailed.
It's Chancellor Gowron. He's requesting permission to dock. They've got wounded.
Permission granted.
This is a dark day, not only for the Klingon Empire, but for the Alpha Quadrant itself.
So what are we going to do about it?
I will do what must be done. Fall back.
Pull my forces out of Cardassian space. Fortify the Klingon Empire. And prepare for a fight to the death.
Maybe there's a better way.
The Khitomer Accords? The treaty between the Federation and the Klingon Empire is dead.

But we can bring it back to life. All it would take is your thumbprint. This is the most fortified position between here and the Klingon Empire. A Starfleet task force will be here soon. If you were to bring your fleet here...
Then we could stand united against the Dominion. And if we do...
We might have a chance.
Think of it. Five years ago no one had ever heard of Bajor or Deep Space Nine. Now all our hopes rest here. Where the tides of fortune take us, no man can know.
They're tricky, those tides.
Five matches. Five victories. You truly have the spirit of Kahless within you.
Until tomorrow.
I'll be waiting.
You've got three broken ribs... maybe four.
They will heal.
Not if you keep fighting they won't. You're lucky you didn't puncture a lung. A body, even a Klingon body, can only take so much punishment.
I will fight.
It is the only honorable thing to do.
He'll lose. And in this condition, he might even die.
Then I will die. But I will not yield.
You heard him. Now bandage his ribs.
I'm sorry. That's absolutely unacceptable. I'm under enough strain as it is, I can't have you quitting on me.

Get a hold of yourself, Garak. After all, you haven't had one of these attacks in years. Yes, this is a tight enclosed space. Yes, there's not a lot of room to move. But a disciplined mind doesn't allow itself to be sidetracked by niggling psychological disorders like claustrophobia. Besides, this isn't like Tzenketh. These walls won't collapse around you. There's plenty of air. And you have friends close by. You have nothing to be concerned about.

Focus on the job. You're the only one who can contact the runabout. People are depending on you. Ziyal is depending on you. You promised her you'd come back. And that young lady has had quite enough disappointments in her life without you adding to them. So control yourself. You're stronger than this. A disciplined mind...
I'm afraid that's the best I can do. Does it feel any better?
Much better.
You're not a very good liar, Mister Worf.
What was that?
It's coming from inside the wall.
Garak.
How long has he been in there?
Maybe half an hour.
Garak. Garak, what is it?
Tell him to stop before they hear him.
Garak, the panel's open. You can come out.
We've got to get him out of there.
Garak. Garak, you have to stop. You're making too much noise.
Garak. Garak.
The light... the light went out.
I know. Come on. I think you can take your break a little early.
It appears he's severely claustrophobic. It's a wonder he lasted as long as he did.
Then one of us will have to finish reconfiguring the transmitter.
And who, would you suggest, could do that?
Exactly.
If Garak can't finish re-aligning the transmitter, we're not going anywhere.
The last of Gowron's ships have arrived.
I'll have repair crews get to work on them right away.
Any word from Starfleet?
Admiral Gilhouly's task force is less than four light years away.
I'll feel a lot better when they get here.
You're not the only one.
(before the lift has even stopped) Captain.
Yes, Major.
I just talked to Odo. Someone overrode the security blocks on the industrial replicator on Level Seventeen.
Sounds like our saboteur. Did they catch him?
No such luck.
Do they know what he replicated?
He wiped the memory core.

Tell Odo I want all security details to pull double shifts as of now. If he needs more men, have him talk to Gowron. I'm sure the Chancellor would be willing to assign some Klingon troops to guard key facilities.
Klingons helping to protect Deep Space Nine. That's an interesting concept.
These are interesting times.
Captain, incoming message. It's Gul Dukat.
In my office.
Dukat.
Please, Captain. Show a little respect. You're talking to the head of the Cardassian government.
I don't recognize that government.
Your recognition is irrelevant.
If that's what you think, then why are we having this conversation?
Because the fact is, Captain, I feel a certain obligation toward you. After all, I freely admit you saved my life on more than one occasion.
Don't remind me.
You should be glad you did. Because now I'm going to return the favor... give you a chance to save your precious Federation. All you have to do is convince them to follow Cardassia's example.
You expect us to join the Dominion?
I expect you to behave rationally. Joining the Dominion will save billions of lives. And keep the Federation from fading into the mists of history.
By allowing it to exist under Dominion rule? No thank you.
I'm afraid you'll like the alternative even less.
Dukat, if you have something to say to me, say it.
I'll make it simple then... A few days ago, I swore that all Cardassia had lost would be regained. That space station you're so fond of was built by Cardassia.
Funny, I thought it was built by Bajoran slave labor.
Either surrender the station, or I'll take it by force. The choice is yours.
You want to retake this station, Dukat? You're welcome to try.
Seven battles and seven victories. Could any hero of legend have done as well?
Heroes of legend do not ache this much.

Your Federation friends have taught you modesty. But this is no time for modesty. When we return to the Klingon Empire, I will seek out Keedera himself and tell him your glorious tale, and he will write a song worthy of you.
Make sure to send me a copy.
I'll do better than that. I'll make sure Keedera mentions you... the healer who bound the warrior's wounds so he could fight again.
Right now, the only part of that song I want to hear is the verse that tells of our escape.
What good is defeating every Jem'Hadar soldier in this compound if it doesn't bring us any closer to freedom?
We have to come up with a new escape plan.
That won't be necessary.
Our original plan will work. I just have to finish what I started. After all, a verse about how the Cardassian panicked in the face of danger would ruin General Martok's song.
And that would be unfortunate.
Now, if you'll excuse me... Garak stands up, shaky but determined.
My dungeon awaits.
There is no greater enemy than one's own fears.
It takes a brave man to face them.

Your asparagus with yamok sauce. The last of my fresh asparagus, I might add. Not that I'll need to stock it anymore. Somehow I get the feeling there won't be much of a demand for human food once the Jem'Hadar are finished with this place.
Aren't you being a little pessimistic?

Am I? The Jem'Hadar don't eat, don't drink, and they don't have sex. And if that wasn't bad enough, the Founders don't eat, don't drink, and they don't have sex either. Which, between you and me, makes my financial future less than promising.
It might not be so bad. For all we know the Vorta could be gluttonous, alcoholic sex maniacs.
I never thought of that.
I wonder what their favorite food is?
Good news. The Starfleet task force under Admiral Gilhouly has entered Bajoran space.
I hope they know what they're in for.
First they demand we come out here, then they make us wait.
They are worthy fighters, but they have no sense of honor.
Is there no Jem'Hadar willing to face me?
Fascinating. Even after all he's been through, the Klingon still thirsts for battle. Doesn't he ever tire of it?
I never do.
You fight because that's what you were designed to do. All that motivates him is some barbaric sense of honor.
And that is something you will never understand. Prepare yourself. I've found you a worthy opponent.
Where is he?
Right in front of you.
Victory is life.
Today is a good day to die.
Jem'Hadar.
Can we get him out?
No time.
The Cardassian. Where is he?
Outside, I suppose.
He's not outside.
What do you want with him?
He is to be put to death.
Sir.
Now, if you wish to live, explain this.
The Bird of Prey Y'tem is in position.
That's everybody.
Major, commander, report to the Defiant.
Yes, sir. SISKO Good luck.
Good luck.
Deploy the runabouts.
Runabout Yukon, prepare for departure.
Ready.
Launch doors are open. You're clear to go in three, two, one. Now.
Engines engaged.
Runabouts deployed.
Sir, I'm reading a large tachyon buildup. Multiple vectors. Ships decloaking!
Romulans.
They're requesting permission to join the fleet.
I'll be damned. Permission granted.
Defiant to Ops.
Go ahead, Major.
Sensors have just detected Dominion and Cardassian ships entering Bajoran space. ETA... ten minutes.
I ask you for the last time, what is this?
It's either a self-sealing stem bolt or a reverse ratcheting router, I'm not sure which.
She's next.
Sir! If you'll allow me.
Worf, honor has been satisfied. Stay down.
Finish this.
What do you see?
My people have a saying. Never turn your back on a Breen.
Doctor, would you please keep the noise down. I'm trying to work in here.
How many transtator circuits do you have left?
Three.
Well work fast. Pretty soon we're going to be up to our necks in Jem'Hadar.
Enough, Klingon. You have proven your worth.
Worf, you heard him. Enough.
I will not yield.
What are you waiting for? End this.
It's over.
It's not over.
You heard him.
I yield.
You what?
I yield. I cannot defeat this Klingon. All I can do is kill him. And that no longer holds my interest.
Shoot them both.
Got it!
Get him to one of the cabins in the back. I'll be right with you.
You did well.
So did you.
Take her to maximum warp. We've got to get a message through to the station.
The Dominion fleet should be in visual range.
On screen.
Where are they?
According to the warp signatures, they should be right there.
Some kind of cloaking device?
I didn't know the Dominion had them.
or the Cardassians for that matter.
I'm reading additional warp signatures. Bearing one-eight- three mark nine-seven. Two-four- four mark twelve. Three-oh-two mark one-three-three.
Defiant to Ops.
Go ahead.
Sir, according to our sensor readings, there're Dominion ships all around us. But we can't see them or get any kind of targeting lock.
We're reading the same thing.
They're everywhere.
Captain, what are your orders?
Chief, I need targets.
I'm trying. But I can't get anything. We may have to wait for them to open fire and then... Captain, I'm receiving a priority one message from the Gamma Quadrant. It's... Doctor Bashir.
Bashir? Computer, locate Doctor Bashir.
Doctor Bashir is not on the station.
What was his last known location?
Doctor Bashirls last known location was Runabout Pad "E."
Sisko to Defiant.
Go ahead.
Major, you have new orders. I want you to find the Yukon and destroy it at any cost. Is that clear?
Yes, sir. Commander.
The Yukon is headed straight for the Bajoran sun.
Its shields are holding.
How can that be?
It looks like someone's been doing some modifications to the Yukon. I'm also picking up large amounts of trilithium, tekasite, and proto- matter on board.
A bomb. If it explodes inside the sun...
It could trigger a supernova. Wipe out the entire fleet... the station...
And Bajor... We have to use the tractor beams.
We're too far.
Wanna bet? Take us to warp.
Inside a solar system?
If we don't, there won't be a solar system left.
The runabout's been destroyed.
If the sun had gone nova, it would've wiped out the Dominion fleet too. Chief, scan for those warp signatures again.
Captain...
They're gone, aren't they?
All I'm reading is normal background radiation.

The warp signatures must've been faked. The Dominion's real fleet never left Cardassian space. This was all an elaborate trap... an attempt to destroy the station and Bajor, and cripple the Federation and Klingon fleets... without ever firing a shot. Tell our friends out there to stand down. Armageddon will have to wait for another day.
Ziyal.
I told you I'd be back.
I never doubted it.
Over a month? I've been hanging around with a changeling for over a month?
You never even suspected it wasn't me?
The worst part is, the clues were right in front of me.
What clues?
He was... so much easier to get along with.
I suppose this means you're going to want your Klingon Opera collection back.
Intact.
More or less.
Then it's settled. In light of the new treaty and the continued Dominion threat to the Alpha Quadrant, there will be a permanent Klingon military presence on this station.
But I choose their commander.
Agreed.
Mister Worf thinks very highly of you, General.
(looks warily toward Gowron) And I think highly of him.
Then I can't think of a better man for the job. If you'll take it?
I would be... honored.
Ops to Sisko.
Sisko here.
You're receiving an incoming message. It's from Dukat.
Captain, I must congratulate you. If that proto-matter device had gone off inside the sun... well, the death toll would've been enormous.
And your daughter would've been one of the casualities.
Ziyal made her choice. As far as I'm concerned, she's no longer my daughter.
You know, I thought you'd changed in the last five years. I see I was wrong.
One man's villain is another man's hero. You should see the monument they're erecting in my honor at the gateway to the Imperial Plaza.
Is that why you sold out your people to the Dominion? For a monument?
What I did I did to make Cardassia strong again. And mark my words, captain. I succeeded. You may have escaped defeat this day... but tomorrow...
We'll see about tomorrow.
Yes. We will.
Don't you think you might've overpacked that bag?
It'll close.
You don't have to take everything all at once. It's not like you're moving to Bajor. One G Twelve is practically right next door.
I know. But I'm not moving to one G twelve.
I found some great quarters in section M.
That's all the way on the other side of the habitat ring.
Dad, don't get all sentimental on me.
I don't have a son.
Go ahead, make jokes. But one day you'll be standing where I am, and believe me, you won't like it any more than I do.
Maybe, but right now, I'm standing here. And I can't wait to spend my first night in my own place.
See. I told you I'd get it.
Okay, let's see if I've got this straight. I can visit any time I want, but I have to call first. You won't be available for breakfast or lunch, but I can count on one dinner a week.
Some weeks, maybe even two.
I've raised a generous young man. You and Nog, moving in together. I can remember when I didn't even want you talking to him.
Things change.
They sure do.
Come in.
Oh. It's you.
Who'd you think it was?
Nog.
How could it be Nog? His ship hasn't even docked yet.
I guess I wasn't thinking.
So what else is new?
Can I help it if I'm excited? My son is coming home.
Root beer. His favorite. I don't know how to thank you, brother.
Ten slips of latinum ought to do it.
You think he'd mind if I had one for myself?
I'd mind. My own brother drinking root beer. It's so... Human.
Mmmm... And bubbly.
That's him, that's him.
Rom.
Just kidding. Come in.
Wrong again.
Constable. Care for a root beer?
No. But you do have something I want.
Whatever it is, I didn't do it.
Don't tell me. Tell the Federation Grand Jury on Inferna Prime.
Federation Grand Jury? Brother, what have you done now?
I haven't done anything. What do they want to talk to me for?
Oh, I think you know.
Odo, I have no idea what this is about.
Then you'll have eight days to try to guess. We leave immediately.
We?
I've been waiting ten years for you to get what you deserve. And now that the big moment is here, I wouldn't miss it for anything.
Let's go.
Brother.
What?
I'll say "hi" to Nog for you.
So, how much longer until we reach Inferna Prime?
Oh, I'd say... one hundred and ninety-one hours and seventeen minutes... give or take a day.
In that case, we'd better find something to keep ourselves occupied. Care for a game of fizzbin?
I don't play cards.
I'll teach you. It's a very simple game.
Let me put it another way... I don't want to play cards. And even if I did, I wouldn't want to play with you.
Afraid you'd lose?

You know, Odo, I used to think all your problems stemmed from the fact that you were a changeling, isolated from your own kind, forced to live among strangers who didn't understand you. You couldn't eat, you couldn't drink, you couldn't sleep, you couldn't make love. Was it any wonder you had such a bad disposition?

But now... you're not a changeling anymore. You're one of us. Life is yours for the taking. All you have to do is reach out and grab it. But do you? No. Because changeling or solid, you're still a miserable, self-hating misanthrope. That's who you are and that's who you'll always be.
I'm still not playing cards with you.
Fine, we'll just sit here for a week in silence.
So what are you reading?
Nothing you'd be interested in.
Don't be so sure.
Quark, give that back.
What are you going to do? Arrest me?

"He walked toward her, the wooden deck heaving to and fro beneath his booted feet. Her hands moved to the broach at her throat. She unclasped it and the cloak fell from her shoulders, her wet skin glistening in the moonlight. Lightning flashed and heaven's thunder roared in rhythm with the beating of their hearts."
All right. Enough.
Odo, I take it all back. You're obviously a lot more complicated than I thought. If you like that kind of thing I might be willing to sell you my first edition of "Vulcan Love Slave."

This is work, not recreation. (can see Quark doesn't buy it) Books like this give me insight into the criminal mind. It's a well known fact that a sizable percentage of homicides are motivated by romantic obsession.
Well, no one gets killed in "Vulcan Love Slave," but it's still a hell of a read.

Give it up, Quark. You can bait me, annoy me, question my very existence, but in the end, we both know I've won. Because when all is said and done, I'll be heading back to D.S. Nine and you'll be spending the rest of your life in a Federation penal colony.
I'm not there yet.
I'm afraid I can't do that. This is a high-security investigation and I'm not allowed to discuss the specifics with anyone. Now, if you don't mind... I have some reading to do.
Cadet Nog reporting for duty, sir.
At ease, cadet. Have a seat.
Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.
You know, I remember when I did my sophomore year field study. Starbase One Thirty-seven. I was a little apprehensive when I got there. But it turned out to be one of the best experiences of my life.
Yes, sir.
The key to field study is simple. Keep your eyes and ears open, follow orders and try not to get in the way.
Yes, sir. Very good, sir. I won't let you down.
Now, on a personal note... I'd like to say how glad I am that you and Jake are going to be roommates.
Yes, sir.
I'm sure the two of you are going to have a lot of fun together.
Yes, sir. Time permitting, sir. I mean, if I'm not too busy. After all, I am here to work.
Don't worry, sir. I'll look after him for you. Set a good example. Keep him out of trouble.
You inspire me with confidence, cadet. Dismissed.
How'd it go?
I inspire him.
Congratulations. Now don't let him down.
You can count on me, sir.
Lights.
So what do you think?
I think I've died and gone to the Divine Treasury. After living in cadet barracks for the past year, this is going to be paradise.
I know exactly what you mean. We're on our own, with no one to tell us what to do.
Before we unpack, we should call maintenance to clean this place.
They were here yesterday.
If you want something done right, you have to do it yourself.
I'll do the cleaning on the odd- numbered days, and you'll do it on the even ones.
We're going to clean every day?
No. Just the odd and even ones.
I'd better start bringing in my things. I don't want to be up too late unpacking.
So what do you feel like doing tonight? Dom-jot... Holosuites... ?
I wish I could. But once we eat and unpack, it'll be time for bed. Lights out at twenty-two hundred.
I haven't gone to bed that early since I was twelve.
Go to sleep whenever you want. But don't forget, we're hitting the gym at oh-four-thirty.
The gym?
Muscles, Jake.
I've heard of them.
Good. Because by the time I'm done with you, you're going to have some of your very own.
You're doing it again.
Doing what?
Smacking your lips.
No I'm not.
There. Don't you hear that?
For the last four days, all I've heard is you complaining.
This whole runabout is alive with annoying little noises. Listen.
To what?
That buzzing sound.
I don't hear a thing.
It started over an hour ago.
If you don't like the noises in here, why don't you go into the back?
Because it's even colder back there than it is up here.
Quark, leave the temperature controls alone.
I will. As soon as I get it right.
There it is again.
What?
That buzzing noise. Don't you hear it?
With all this lip-smacking how could I hear anything?
Where is it coming from?
Inside your head.
Bzzzzzzzzz.
I said be quiet.
It's coming from in here.
It's probably a defective anodyne circuit.
Defective anodyne circuits make a kind of... hissing sound. This is a buzz. We've got to open up the panel.
If this is some kind of convoluted plot to escape...
Stop being so suspicious.
That's odd. The buzzing's changed pitch.
Let's find out.
Don't tell me. Let me guess.
It's a bomb.
Next time I tell you I hear something, maybe you'll listen.
Let's hope there is a next time.
I'm going to get a transporter lock on that thing and beam it out of here.
What if it's set to go off if someone tries to transport it?
What do you suggest we do? Wait for it to explode?
I hope this works.
We did it. We're safe.
I wouldn't be so sure about that.
The comm system's down. The navigational array's failing. Environmental controls are badly damaged. We're losing atmosphere.
Now what?
Now we find someplace to land.
Land? You mean crash.
It's either that or wait for our lungs to explode in the vacuum of space.
I'm picking up a Class-L planet on long range scanners.
Barely habitable.
More habitable than this thing's going to be in a few minutes.
How close?
Close enough. I hope.
If we live through this, whoever planted that bomb is going to regret it.
Believe me, you don't want to go anywhere near the Orion Syndicate.
The Orion Syndicate? Is that who the Grand Jury's investigating?
I thought you knew.
If I knew you were involved with the Orion Syndicate, you'd be on the Defiant right now, surrounded by half my deputies.
Let me guess. You were pretending to know more than you did so I'd think I had nothing to hide and say something to incriminate myself.
(his eyes fixed on the window) Something like that.
This is all your fault.
You're the one who's a member of the Orion Syndicate.
I'm not a member. I just know people who know people who know some other people. And besides...
Ahhhhhh!
Someone adjust the temperature. It's freezing in here.
Actually, it's freezing out there.
Out there? Oh yeah. I remember now. You were apologizing for almost getting us both killed.
If that's how you remember it, you must've hit your head harder than I thought.
I guess there's nothing we can do now except send out a distress signal and wait to be rescued.
Good plan. Except we lost the comm system in the explosion.
That's not good.
It gets worse. The replicator's been destroyed and from what I can tell the local plants are poisonous.
Then I guess we're stuck with field rations.
That's right. (distributing the rations) One package for you. And one package for me. The rest were...
I know, I know. Destroyed in the explosion. So now what?
Now we either freeze to death or starve to death. Take your pick.
It's about time you woke up. I thought you were going to sleep all day.
You should stretch a little before you start your workout.
I think I'll pass this morning.
You pass every morning.
You can work out for the both of us.
You don't know what you're missing. "Healthy body, healthy mind."
Please. No cliches before breakfast.
Orange juice. Extra large. A healthy way to start your day.
A writer and a poet.
What's this?
"Past Prologue."
What's it doing out here?
I found it while I was cleaning up. Really Jake, is it that hard to put things away when you're done with them?
You read my story? What did you think?
"Disposal" is spelled with an "i"
That's it? That's all you have to say?
I didn't really read it for content. I mostly corrected your spelling and grammar.
You changed my words?
Just a few. A preposition here, some punctuation there.
You can't change a writer's words without his permission. That's sacrilege.
All right. Next time, I'll let you make the changes.
There won't be a next time. From now on, if you see my stories lying around, don't read them. Don't even touch them. Just leave them right where they are.
No problem. Just put them away when you're not working on them.
Time to hit the shower. Duty calls.
Remember, start with the lighter weights then work your way up.
Quark? What are you doing back there?
Do you need any help?
You want to help? Here.
I thought you were supposed to be repairing the subspace transmitter.
I was.
Then what's it doing out here?
The signal booster's completely shot.
Which means there's no way we can transmit a distress signal through a planetary atmosphere.
I see. So you tore it out of the wall in frustration.

Actually, I've come up with a way to save our lives. All we have to do is haul this transmitter up to higher ground. More altitude, less atmosphere. Go high enough, and we might be able to get a signal out.
How much higher do we have to go?
Hmmm... carry the seven, take the square root, times pi... I'd say...
That high.
I'm ready when you are.
(re: the cold weather gear) Where'd you find that?
In the back. It's pretty cozy.
Great. Then I won't need this. (he takes off the blanket) I'll go get a suit for myself and we can be on our way.
Don't bother. This is the only one that wasn't destroyed in the explosion.
So we have one survival suit left and you're going to wear it?
Finders keepers. Besides carrying that transmitter up the mountain should keep you warm.
How can it be so cold when the sun is shining?
It's not much of a sun. And this isn't much of a planet. And you've got a lot of nerve complaining about being cold when you're the one wearing the jacket.
You agreed to take turns.
Under duress.
I hate this. If I were still a changeling, I could've shapeshifted into a Vorian Pterodactyl and flown that damn transmitter to the top of the mountain hours ago.
You're the one who wanted to be a solid.
I never wanted to be a solid.

Oh, please. I used to see you coming into the bar, watching Morn eat, eyeing my customers gambling and flirting with the dabo girls, and wishing you could be one of them. Not to mention your "platonic friendship" with a certain Bajoran major.
If that's the kind of psychological insight you dispense with your drinks, it's a wonder you have any customers.
Deny it all you want. But the fact is your people gave you what you wanted. You're one of us now.
And I finally can sit on a chair and know with absolute certainty that it isn't you.
Quark? If you've damaged that transmitter...
I'm fine, thank you very much. And so's the transmitter.
Let me help you up.
No thanks. I think I'll just lay here and freeze to death.
You've made your point. I'll carry the transmitter for a while.
And I get to wear the jacket.
But I get the trousers.
You did a good job today, Nog. You've got an excellent grasp of mechanical engineering.
Ferengis have a natural talent for figures, sir.
So where are you posted tomorrow?
Cargo Bay Six, sir. Customs inspection.
That could be... interesting.
(not looking forward to it) If you're planning on being a customs inspector.
Hey, Nog.
Not again. When I left this morning, this place was spotless.
That was nine hours ago.
You can't keep our quarters clean for one day?
A man's got to live. And sometimes living is messy.
But it doesn't have to stay messy. I'm going to the Replimat to get something to eat. When I come back I expect to see this place straightened up.
I'm working on a story. I'll do it in the morning.
This isn't a story. It's computerized dom-jot.
Sometimes when I get stuck, I play dom-jot. It clears my mind.
Well while you're at it, how about clearing a path to the bedroom?
I told you, I'm busy.
Jake, this isn't what we agreed to.
We didn't "agree" to anything. You've been shouting orders ever since you moved in here. I'm not in Starfleet.
Lucky for you. You wouldn't last a day at the Academy.
You're right. I'd die of embarrassment wearing those pajamas.
I don't have to take that from an undisciplined jerk like you.
Enjoy your dom-jot.
Where are you going?
Anywhere but here. I'll get my things in the morning.
I'll pack them for you.
Don't bother. You couldn't fold a shirt if your life depended on it.
What's that over there?
It's just another stone.
I can't believe it. We've been walking for two days and we haven't seen a single beetle. I could really go for a beetle right now. Any kind of beetle, just as long as it had a little meat on it.
There are no beetles, Quark.
A nice slug would do.
There're no slugs, either. No slugs, no beetles, no worms, no snails. There's nothing here but trees and rocks and we can't eat any of it.
If I collapse from hunger, you're going to have to carry me and the transmitter.
You're not going to collapse. We're almost to the tree line. After that, we'll only have a few hours of climbing left before we can set up the transmitter.
A few hours? You mean like three?
More like six.
I can do six. Seven might be pushing it, but six I can do.
Forget about six hours. How about six days?
Ten thousand, seven hundred, fifty- one. Ten thousand seven hundred, fifty-two.
(getting a little sick of this) Quark.
Ten thousand, seven hundred --
Quark.
I just want to know how far we're going. Every step down means one extra step up.
Then count to yourself. I don't want to hear it any more.
Fine. But don't talk to me. It's hard keeping track.
(ignoring Quark's request) By the time the grand jury's through with you, you'll be counting years instead of steps.
(still counting in his head) You know what's going to make all this worthwhile? The look on your face when they let me go.
Let you go? I don't think so.

And you call yourself a detective. The Orion Syndicate tried to kill me. They never kill their own. They don't need to. Any one of them would take their own life before they'd testify against the Syndicate. Don't you get it? I'm not a suspect. I'm a witness. Now you made me lose count.
Ten thousand, seven hundred, and sixty-eight.
Thank you.
So let me get this straight... you were never a member of the Orion Syndicate.
I hate to disappoint you.
But you must've tried to join?
I don't want to talk about it.
If I remember correctly, the Orion Syndicate has a membership fee... quite a substantial one.
And the Ferengi Commerce Authority did seize all your assets.

It's even worse than that isn't it? You never could afford to join, could you? All those years of lying and scheming and cheating, and you were still too small-time for the Orions. I guess you're not as successful a businessman as you think you are.
Which means you've spent the last ten years of your life trying to catch a nobody. Without much success, I might add. So you tell me, which one of us is the bigger failure.
Ten thousand, eight hundred. Ten thousand, eight hundred and one...
Snail juice. Extra shells. Make it a double.
May I join you?
Be my guest.
I wanted to ask you... about my son. You know? Nog?
I think I've met him.
Have you noticed anything... strange about him lately?
He seems fine to me. He's just more... dedicated than when he left.
I've noticed.
A year at the Academy can do that to people.
You think it's the Academy?
What else could it be?
I was afraid he might be a changeling. So while he was asleep, I drew some blood, just to make sure.
It's been eight hours. So far so good.
Rom, he's still your son. He's just taking his duties very seriously, that's all.
Tell me about it. Nog's moved back in with me, you know. It's horrible. He put me on report the other day. Said my tool kit was untidy. That's the exact word he used. "Untidy."
I wouldn't worry about it. It's just a phase he's going through.
I was hoping living with Jake would relax him.
I'm afraid Jake's going through a phase of his own. I don't know what's so difficult about putting a dirty plate back in the replicator.
I don't know what's so difficult about putting a dirty plate back in the replicator.
Nog says Jake is a "slovenly, undisciplined, unfocused... " (imitating his son, with disdain) "Writer."
Not an unfair assessment, I'm afraid. Sometimes I wish Jake had a little of Nog's self-discipline.
And I wish Nog had Jake's ability to enjoy himself.
Those two could learn a lot from each other.
If we could only get them in the same room.
Quark, wake up.
Come on, Quark. We've got a mountain to climb.
Quark.
Quark!
Wake up.
Stop hitting me.
I thought you were dead.
And you saw that as an opportunity to vent years of hostility towards me.
Towards me. Towards me. Hostility.
What's wrong?
What?
I said what's the matter.
I'm deaf. (he clutches his right ear) I'm deaf in my right ear. I can't hear anything out of it. (testing, covering his right ear) Hello, hello, hello. Hello, hello, hello.
Would you stop doing that?
You don't understand. A one-eared Ferengi is only half a man. We've got to get out of here. My body's shutting down. It's too cold. There's not enough food. I'm dying. we both are.
We're not going to die.
Here. You can have the rest of my rations.
These aren't rations. These are crumbs. You can't climb a mountain on crumbs.
Fine. I'll go myself.
You're going to leave me?
What do you want me to do? Stay here and trade insults until we starve to death? I'd rather take my chances on the mountain.
Whose turn is it to carry the transmitter?
Yours.
Figures. Figures. Figures!
I hate this transmitter. I hate this mountain. And most of all I hate the Orion Syndicate for stranding us here.
I think we both know who's really to blame.
Don't try to blame this on me, "Constable." It was your job to get me to Inferna Prime safely.
You never told me the Orion Syndicate was after you.
You never asked.
If I had, would you have told me the truth? Or would you have lied like you lie about everything?
Have I ever told you how much I hate that smug, superior attitude of yours?
Have I ever told you how much I hate your endless whining, your pathetic greed and your idiotic little schemes?
Well I hate...
What do you hate?
You.
That's fine with me. Because I hate you too. You're nothing but a petty thief.
And you... are an arrogant prude.
Lecher.
Freak.
Fraud.
Fascist.
Failure.
Quark?
What?
Are you all right?
I'm fine.
I'm not.
This should hold together.
Now we just have to get you on it.
Stop looking at the leg. You'll pass out again.
Not looking at it doesn't help. I still know it's there.
I should be the one struggling to stay conscious. I'm the one in excruciating pain.
Speaking of pain, this is probably going to hurt.
Quark, there's no way you're going to be able to drag me up this mountain.
Watch me.
Stop trying to be a hero. You'll reach the top faster if you leave me behind.
You don't get it, do you? I'm not trying to rescue you. I'm taking you along as emergency rations. If you die, I'm going to eat you.
You're joking.
Waste not, want not.
Comfortable?
Not really.
Join the club.
Quark...
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: It's over.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What do you mean over?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I can't move. We'll have to set up the transmitter here.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: We're not high enough. You have to leave me here and go on yourself.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Don't you understand? I can't do it. I'm half frozen and I haven't eaten for two days. My muscles won't work anymore.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Odo?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Well say something.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What's there to say? If we stay here, we're dead.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I can't go any farther.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: If Sisko were here, do you think he'd give up? Or Worf? Or Dax?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: They're not here.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: That's right. It's just us.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Give me the transmitter.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What for?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I said, give it to me.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What are you doing?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What does it look like?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: You'll never make it.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Maybe not.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: You're trying to embarrass me, aren't you? You're trying to shame me into carrying that thing the rest of the way on my own.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: It's not going to work. You might as well accept the inevitable and die with dignity. That's what I'm going to do. I'm just going to sit here... and die. (a beat, softly, to himself) my brother will get the bar, my nephew will be completely corrupted by the Federation and end up a Starfleet captain, and my bones will lie here and freeze... unsold and unmourned.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Try not to break your other leg while I'm gone.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I'll do my best.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Good luck.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Come in.
Dad? I though you were going to call first.
Jake. We've got a problem.
What's wrong?
According to station regulations, these quarters require two or more occupants. I'm afraid you're going to have to move out.
Smaller quarters. All right, if I have to.
I'm afraid that's the problem, Jake. We don't have any smaller quarters available.
So where do I go?
I guess back home with me.
You're kidding.
Unless we can find you a roommate.
Cadet.
Sir, I really must protest.
Cadets don't have that privilege.
And neither do you. Now I know that you're two very different people, but you're still friends. And somehow, some way, you'll make this work.
I don't know.
Neither do I.
Well I do.
And I'm your captain... And your father. So what I say goes. Good day, gentlemen.
The place hasn't changed much, has it?
I guess not. Are you going to start cleaning again?
No, I've got to study.
Good, because it would take a while to clean up this... pigsty.
It's not so bad.
It's bad.
Yeah.
You want to go to the gym?
Healthy body, healthy mind.
I got a better idea. How about a game of dom-jot? I'll let you break.
Quark?
Quark?

Begin recording. Chief of Security's log, final entry. It looks like Quark didn't make it. I can't say I'm surprised. You'll find his body farther up the slope. No doubt, he'd want you to vacuum-desiccate his remains and auction them off. Not that they're worth anything. As for myself...
Cremate me, stick my ashes in my bucket, and shoot me through the wormhole. I may as well end up where I began. Or better yet...
Prepare an IV drip of poly- nutrient solution.
I'm alive.
And I'm going to see you stay that way.
Quark?
We found him on top of the mountain. He was slumped over a subspace transmitter.
You mean he made it?
If it wasn't for his signal, we never would've found you. Looks like he saved both your lives.
I was afraid you'd say that.
Odo? You awake?
I am now.
We survived.
We did.
I bet you were surprised that I actually made it all the way to the top.
Astounded.
You remember back there, when I said I hated you?
Vividly?
I just wanted you to know... I meant every word of it.
So did I.
You wanted to see me, Garak?
Constable, how good of you to stop by.
Shoplifter?
Excuse me?
What do you think?
"A thing of beauty is a joy forever."
Put it on my account. I'll wear it to work.
A splendid idea.
Security Chief Odo, allow me to introduce Chalan Aroya. One of my best customers.
I'm familiar with it.
I watch you walk by every morning on patrol. Oh nine thirty-seven. You're very precise.
How... nice of you to notice.
I was hoping one day you might stop in. When you're not working.
I don't eat.
I do. And I hate to eat alone. Think about it.
And next time you're on the Second Level, don't forget to say "hello."
The next time you call me, it'd better be to report a crime.
Now that you mention it, I just witnessed a crime. Letting Aroya walk out of here without arranging a date. You should be locked away for that.
You humanoids. You're all obsessed with these convoluted mating rituals of yours.

True. But do you think we'd waste so much time on something that wasn't worthwhile? I'll never understand you. You're such a curious man, yet there're so many aspects of humanoid life you simply refuse to explore.
I have no desire to become a slave to humanoid obsessions.
But you have to admit, she was quite lovely.
She was, wasn't she?
Odo, what's wrong?
I don't know.
Garak to Doctor Bashir. I need a medical emergency team sent to my shop, immediately.
Doctor, this is a waste of time. You don't know enough about changeling physiology to diagnose what's wrong with me. No one does.

Actually, I do have some idea what's going on. I've compared your current medical scans with ones I've made over the last four years and there're noticeable differences. Normally when you're in humanoid form, you have a specific density of one point four which is consistent throughout your body. Your mass and density only vary when you change shape. But right now, your mass and density are in a state of fluctuation.
Do you know what's causing it?
No.
Do you know how to prevent it from happening again?
Then tell me when you do.
I'm afraid I can't let you leave just yet. Moving seems to increase the fluctuations. And that could bring on another attack.
Are you saying that I have to lie here until you discover a cure?
or until the fluctuations stop on their own. For all I know, this could be a normal biological process, the changeling equivalent of puberty or menopause.
That's an interesting theory. One I suggest you keep to yourself.
